Dear Ms. Wilson:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
4/14/2025. An exit conference was held with your agency on 4/18/2025. Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
DCWL- Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
(1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for all the areas of foster care services as
provided in R400.12203 to R 400.12214.
The agency requires its employees to complete annual ICHATs and central registry
clearances. Two of five employee records reviewed where the employee had been
employed over one year showed the respective employee's annual central record
clearance was completed after its 4/25/2024 and 3/5/2025 annual due date.
Repeat Violation Established:
2024 Renewal, CAP approved 5/10/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to
the time of the change in placement and the needs that
remain to be met.
Two of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of the
summary of services and needs that remain to be met, as required by the rule.
2

CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
Two of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
whether there were provisions for any continuing services, as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368,
MCL 333.5111. All the following apply:
(ii) A copy of a waiver addressed to the department that
is signed by the parent stating immunizations are not
being administered due to religious, medical, or other
reasons is sufficient documentation of immunizations,
unless the child is a temporary ward, a motion is heard,
and order is entered by the circuit court for the child's
case. A waiver must be accompanied by a certification
by the local health department that the parent or parents
received education on the risks of not receiving the
vaccines being waived and the benefits of vaccination to
the individual and the community as required by section
5111 of the public health code, 1978 PA 368, MCL
333.5111, and R 325.176(12).
Two of six open foster child records reviewed showed that three to four of the
respective child's immunizations had expired, and the record did not show
documentation of a parental waiver.
Repeat Violation Established:
2024 Renewal, CAP approved 5/10/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact.
3

(4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
siblings who are not placed together except when there
is a court determination that contact is detrimental to
either child.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of an
April 2024, July 2024, or February 2025 sibling visit.
Repeat Violation Established:
2024 Renewal, CAP approved 5/10/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
Four of six adoptive family evaluations reviewed showed the family's evaluation was
not completed within 90 days of the family's application date, as required by the
rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/12/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption
with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation and
recommendation upon its completion.
Three of six adoptive family records reviewed did not show documentation that the
family received a copy of their respective February 2025 and March 2025 adoption
evaluations.

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
During this licensing inspection period the agency submitted two acceptable
corrective action plans.
The first corrective action plan related to Special Investigation 2024SIC000119
were the intake was received on 2/26/2024. The complaint alleged an employee
violated confidentiality. During the special investigation the evidence supported
the allegations, and the agency was found in violation of R400.12211 for Privacy
safeguard. The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan that was
approved on 9/24/2024. The agency has implemented this corrective plan.
The second corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2024 Renewal
inspection where the agency was found in violation of 8 rule violations. During this
2025 Interim inspection 3 violations were repeat violations from 2024, and 1 is a
repeat violation from 2023. The agency’s corrective action plan compliance
around these 4 rule violations is as follows: the number of individual cases cited
remained the same with respect to 2 citations, deceased on 1 citation and
increased on the remaining 1 repeat violation from 2023 that went from 1 of 5 to 3
of 6. The agency contributed the latter increase to poor documentation, which it
reports it continues to work on.
A review of the agency’s 2024 Renewal corrective action plan showed completed
and/or implemented all aspects of the corrective plan, though that implementation
did not result in complete compliance of all licensing rules during this inspection.
Further corrective action planning is required to achieve compliance and the
agency indicated it will continue striving for full compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator’s (CA) report dated 4/1/2025. The CA
report indicated various areas it has achieved full or partial compliances in, such
as adoption assessments and adoption quarterlies related to the former and
treatment plans and dental policy related to the latter. It also indicated barriers
which impacted full compliance. Barriers indicated were workers and supervisors
not consistently ultilizing departmental checklists to cross reference items; workers
failing to consistently reference the Book of Business and Data Warehouse
system; or not following policy guidelines. The CA report indicated the corrective
action plan brought attention to areas that more attention and oversight was
needed and provided supervisors with guidelines to improve and provide workers
5

with a check and balance system to aid them in meeting metric numbers. The
chief administrator reported that the agency’s’ goal is to strive for total compliance
for the next year.
The chief administrator identified the agency’s strengths as team work, ability to
communicate and problem solve; and that it was able to gain attention this year
via a local new station to bring attention to what the agency does. Challenges
indicated by the chief administrator were staff turnover, case close outs not
occurring timely due to orders not being uploaded from other entities, Wayne
County adoption timeframes for signing orders, parent cancelling visits,
medical/dental offices not being able to re-schedule visits until after the due date,
and not enough foster homes for replacements. All of these are areas the agency
must continue to focus on and develop interpersonal communications and put
forth collaborative work efforts.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted a 2025 annual foster care and adoption budget; as well as
a copy of its 9/30/2024 independent financial audit. A review of these documents
did not show indications of any notable areas of concern.
Staff Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the chief administrator, the licensing supervisor
and adoption supervisor, I interviewed one foster care worker, one licensing
worker and one adoption worker. All the staff reported positives about the agency,
the managerial staff, and indicated feeling supportive and respected. All these
staff reported that everyone helps one another, there is good team
communication, overall good agency communication; and that the agency is a
worthwhile place to work. An area of growth reported related to gaining greater
staff retention.
Description of Agency Walk Through
During a tour of the agency's facility, I did not observe any safety issues or
concerns. The agency has sufficient space and equipment for its employees, and
files are securely stored.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts during this inspection period.
6

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
